review: Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization IV is an addicting 4X strategy game. As a leader of one of the eighteen civilizations of the base game (that can become even more with the two expansions, Warlords and Beyond the Sword) the player is expected to explore the surrounding lands (in a potentially procedurally generated map) and expand their city borders, found new cities or conquer others to gradually become an empire and eventually win a campaign that spans from the stone age to the near future of 2050. Victory can be achieved in many ways, from being the first civilization to reach outer space, to remaining the only civilization that is left on the map. The most interesting and addicting factor of Civilization IV are the choices the player takes, each one leading their civilization‚Äôs progress in a different direction. The technology tree is interesting and varied, allowing to focus on military prowess in one game or scientific progress in another; each choice could be the better one, depending on the map, the adversaries and the success in building world wonders or founding religions. Accompanying these potentially endless games are decent graphics that are clear to understand despite the complexity of the system and an incredibly (and award winning!) soundtrack. The Warlord expansion adds six more civilizations, more leaders and unique scenarios to the main game, but is otherwise unremarkable. The Beyond the Sword expansions is a lot better, adding ten more civilizations, more leaders, more unique scenarios and late game buildings; it also adds natural disasters and expanded victory conditions, making the end game a lot more interesting. Civilization IV ‚Äì The Complete Edition is an amazing package, with virtually endless fours of fun that players want to spend time with, even if just for‚Ä¶ one‚Ä¶ more‚Ä¶ turn‚Ä¶

Everything I love about Civ IV vanilla is still here and Warlords is a great expansion that adds a lot of extras to the game. There's little reason to buy this expansion if you have Beyond the Sword since everything added in Warlords is also part of BtS EXCEPT the scenarios. review:
This game is so unbelievably unbalanced that it hurts. The fact that on one of the lowest difficulties, the AI will still spawn with unfairly handed out promotions on military units, combined with a barrage of horse archers, and only horse archers, and proceed to skull fuck all of your improvements by autistically running around just out of range of your own units is mind boggling. 

Don't even get me started on the combat odds either. The combat odd system is absolutely insufferable. The sheer fact that when you have a +2 combat odd on a battle between a musketman and a swordsman in open field and your musketman still somehow manages to lose is utterly retarded. Yet, the elation that flows through your body when you rise on top, victorious over all other nations makes you want to keep coming back to this game, as if it is an abusive girlfriend. 

The pleasure that you gain out of playing this timeless game in the Civilisation franchise will show itself every now and then, giving you a little dopamine hit before dragging you down back to the reality of life and making you want to hurl yourself into a crater.

review:
Civilization IV: Warlords is the first expansion to one of the best turn-based strategy games of all time. As this is an expansion, and not the base game, I'm not going to detail all of my thoughts about the game here. Feel free to look up my Civilization IV game review for that.

Pros and Cons specifically for this expansion:

Pros:
+ More civs, more units, etc.
+ Some minor mechanic improvements
+ The Great Generals feature is a new and interesting "hero mechanic" to the series, that adds a bit of flavor to the game.
+ The introduction of vassal states is appreciated. It's especially helpful when you become the dominant player in the game, or when you're going for diplomatic victories.


Cons:
- The Great Generals special unit can be hit or miss in its usefulness. And enemy "stacks of doom" love to target your Generals.

Rating: B+ (for its time), B- (for 2021)

Like the base game, the Warlords expansion can often be found on sale. But even for $5, if you already own the base game, you may find it worth it.

A great addon, that brings up six new civilizations (Celts, Vikings, Carthaginians, Zulu, Koreans, and Ottomans), a dozen leaders (including Churchill and Stalin), warlord and vassal mechanics (allows more powerful civilizations to control weaker civilizations), more units, unique buildings for each nation, three world wonders, resources, game scenarios, as well as a lot of smaller improvements.

As you can guess from the name, Warlords focuses on the military aspects of the game. All its innovations, in one way or another, are designed to diversify the militaristic scenarios. review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#334 out of 612)... it's time for Sins of a Civilization IV: Warlords.

Warlords is a standalone expansion to Civilization IV with a focus on combat, and specific challenging scenarios based on, or at least loosely inspired by, real-life history. It's effectively Civilization IV but less of a sandbox, more of a focused experience. The core systems and mechanics are largely the same, and just as enthralling here as ever. Civilization did not become the preeminent grand strategy series by accident, after all.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

In theory the idea of experience and strength/attack improvements is good, but you get ridiculous situations of attacking a city and your tanks are getting wiped out by defending archers!!!! This is at Chieftan level, the second lowest. The graphics are pretty but I'd take Civ 2 any day as its better as a game. I almost feel I want to buy an old XP machine just to get back to Civ 2. The sounds and graphics are nice but this game has serious flaws.

review:
Following the release of the grand, turning point of a game series known as Civilization IV, Civilization IV - Warlords speaks quite a different story.

Civilization IV's Warlords introduces scenarios that have occured in the real world, and added the missing bit of realism back into Civilization IV. It is somehow more fun than the other expansions and I love it. It is also considered the expansion with a fully functioning PitBoss server. Nonetheless, it is and still is one of the greatest expansions, and added it's own touch of history to said turning point of the game series, Civilization IV. It is just obscured in gaming history.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040303339', 'num_games_owned': 735, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 22127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19477, 'last_played': 1577556215}
review:
Civ IV may sound dated when there's VI out now, but, in my opinion, 4 is the best in the series. And of Civ IV, my favorite flavor (Vanilla, Warlords, Beyond the Sword) is Warlords. The middle child of the set, Warlords adds some nice features without getting bogged down with questionable changes, features, or tech (yes, I'm looking at you, Aesthetics).

For example, in Vanilla and Warlords, you can play a One-City-Challenge game (win with only ever having your original city) and build all of the National Wonders (basically mini-World Wonders that can be built by each player) in that city (usual game limit is 2/city). This made One-City-Challenges fun as you could build a mega-capital, but Beyond the Sword expanded the 2 National Wonders per city limit to include One-City-Challenge games as well.

review:
Tags: TBS - Turn Based Strategy
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: An odd duck in the Civ series. This military oriented expansion is offered as a standalone. Not as clean and simple as Vanilla Civ IV not as rich as Beyond the Sword. Dated compared to newer Civs. 

There is nothing inherently wrong with this game, but it came in an era before DLC and the monetization strategy was to re-release the same game, and charge full price for people wanting the expansion tacked in. This practice was later abandonned. If Civ IV was released in today's climate only beyond the sword would likely remain and be acknowledged and as such I recognize this game as a superfluous relic of a different time. It is still insanely addictive and fun but with the saturation in the genre, and furthermore, with the additional entries in the Civ series it is becoming increasingly obvious to me that I will never actually go back and play this game and would rather keep it archived with the rest of my hidden licenses.
